metadata.title: Google knew I was non-binary before I did | by Ari Joury, PhD | Towards Data Science
metadata.h1: Google knew I was non-binary before I did
metadata.description: My life is ruled by algorithms — from those that I build myself to those that determine which video I’ll watch next. But it got spooky when an algorithm knew I was queer before I did...

all_paragraphs: My life is ruled by algorithms — from those that I build myself to those that determine which video I’ll watch next. But it got spooky when an algorithm knew I was queer before I did — although it was trained to see life in a gender-binary way.
It’s a rainy Sunday afternoon and we’re sitting in the living room. I’m reading a book while you’re stroking Pukey, our cat. You look up to me.
‘I wonder whether cats can be transgender, like you are.’
‘I don’t know. There’s no reason why an animal shouldn’t be transgender. Unfortunately we can’t ask them.’
‘I think Pukey could be trans. She behaves like an alpha male!’
‘Perhaps you’re right. But who knows — it can be really difficult to determine someone’s gender identity from their behavior.’
‘Yeah — most people don’t think that you’re trans when they meet you.’
‘Exactly. Although Google knew that I was non-binary before everyone else!’
‘You heard me right. Google knew that I was non-binary — and I found out through my ad settings.

‘I realized that I was a non-binary transperson back in 2017. I’d felt it all my life, but it took me a long time to find words for my feelings. That moment of realization — that was an epiphany for me.

‘But there was another, smaller moment of epiphany two years prior. I was checking my Google ad settings after an email informed me of their existence. These settings cover things like your age, gender, education, and main areas of interest in order to tailor ads to you.
‘I’d never disclosed my gender to them, but somehow I’d assumed they’d guess my assigned gender based on my activity.
‘That wasn’t the case — it didn’t guess my assigned gender! And Google used both men’s and women’s interests to personalize my ads. Needless to say, I was intrigued by this result.’
‘But why didn’t you realize then that you were transgender?’
Google recognized my queerness. But I took me years to realize that
‘We’re talking 2017, darling. At the time, I didn’t even know the word transgender. Hell, I hardly knew what being gay meant!

‘I’d always assumed that everybody shared my feelings of dysphoria and occasional euphoria. Since my feelings had gotten really large since the onset of puberty, I’d assumed that this struggle with one’s body and one’s identity is the defining element of everyone’s adulthood.

‘I concluded that this struggle was the reason why adults laugh less often than children. That this struggle made adults so boring from a child’s perspective. That this struggle eventually killed people when they got old. That adulthood is just a slow form of dying from a battle against oneself. For everyone.’
‘What a sad view of the world!’
‘In retrospective, yes. Unfortunately I didn’t Google my feelings back then…’
‘How did the people around you react to that worldview?’

‘I never told them about it. But of course I was aware that many other people were getting on much better with their bodies and their genders. So I went on thinking that they were somehow stronger than me because they could handle the struggle of adulthood better than I could. That led to massive feelings of self-doubt and worse.’
‘Yes, but for me the internet was an amazing fix. In that moment when I saw my Google ad settings I realized that I wasn’t weaker or inferior than everyone else.
‘That moment wasn’t a fix-it-all. There were still a lot self-doubts and hard times after that. But my Google ad settings were facts that stuck in the back of my head as the years went by.’
Google must have thought that I was a genderfluid person in a relationship
‘Did you check your ad settings a lot after that?’

‘From time to time, yes. It was intriguing to see how the settings changed with time. Sometimes I was male to Google, but most of the time it thought I was female. Men’s and women’s interests were both present. And Google always thought I was in a relationship, although most of the time I wasn’t. I still haven’t figured out why Google thought that.’
‘Haha, Google thought you were a genderfluid person in a relationship.’
‘Somehow yes. Although I’m not genderfluid — my gender is the same all the time. It’s just neither male nor female.’
‘So probably Google couldn’t decide which gender you are because you neither fit in the male nor the female category?’
‘Probably, yes. But the game changed after I officially came out. I was out to a few close friends by 2018. But it was in 2019 that I started coming out to everyone.

‘From that point in 2019, Google’s ad settings consistently labeled me female. I don’t know exactly why. Perhaps there was a change in its algorithms around that time, making gender assignment less flexible. Or maybe my activity changed after coming out in ways that influenced the way that Google thought about me. I’ll probably never know.’
‘It’s a mystery! And Google is still getting your gender wrong.’
‘And right, at the same time. It’s funny how inherently sexist algorithms can reveal truths about non-conforming people like me. And how that can be a source of relief and freedom for us.’
‘Did you ever consider changing your settings so that Google knows your real gender?’

‘I recently did! The downside to this is that I don’t see Google’s guess of my gender any more. I found it quite interesting to see whether it sees me as male or female. It reveals a lot about Google’s algorithms, and how Google and our society think about the gender-binary.’
‘Did anything change after you disclosed your gender?’
‘Well, suddenly Google thinks that I’m single! Also, the setting for health and beauty immediately disappeared.
‘So according to today’s tech, genderqueer people are rarely in relationships and don’t care a lot about health and beauty. Which is nonsense, if you ask me.’
‘That sounds weird indeed! It’s going to be interesting to see how this changes as people become more tolerant. Will it show you ads tailored to non-binary people?’
‘Let’s wait and see! These ads definitely exist, but we’re yet to find out whether Google does a good job at showing them to me.’
‘It’s a shame that cats can’t use Google as well. We might never find out whether Pukey is transgender.’

‘That will be challenging indeed. But let’s see what the future holds. I’m hopeful that one day we’ll be more educated about gender. Then we might not project our binary stereotypes onto the humans and animals around us any more.’
Your home for data science. A Medium publication sharing concepts, ideas and codes.
Lost in my thoughts, mostly about tech. https://arijoury.medium.com/membership

all_outgoing_urls.anchor_text: A History of YouTube Undermining Its LGBT+ CreatorsGoogle — and with it YouTube — has been taking a clear standing by discriminating LGBT creators. Astonishingly, its own algorithms reveal queerness where it isn’t obvious to the human eye.medium.com
